pages.name: Notice of Lawyer for Party
pages.description:
Rule 161 says that if a case involves a party, the party’s views must be considered unless it is inappropriate to do so.

One way to have the party’s views heard by the court is for a party to have their own lawyer to represent their interests. Other ways include a views of the party report or the judge interviewing the party directly.

Permission of the court is not required for a lawyer to begin representing the interests of a party but a court order may be needed if a lawyer needs to be appointed by the court.

It is up to the court to determine how a party’s evidence will be heard, as appropriate.

elements.name: FAQLegalAdvice1
elements.title: How does a lawyer for a party get appointed?
elements.body:
Where it is in the best interests of a party to be represented in a family law case, any party to the case can apply under s. 203 of the Family Law Act for a lawyer to represent the interests of the party. An application can be made using the Application for Case Management Order in Form 10. You can apply for a case management order using this service.

If the court agrees that it is in the party’s best interests, the court may appoint a lawyer for that party. The order might also include how the lawyer’s fees will be paid and by whom.

Partyren or parents can contact the Society for Partyren and Youth of British Columbia’s Party and Youth Legal Centre for more information about getting a lawyer for a party. The Centre provides legal support for young people.

elements.name: pageIntro
elements.html:
Are you a lawyer representing a party in a family law case?

Rule 162 of the Provincial Court Family Rules requires you to file a Notice of Lawyer for Party in Form 40 when you start representing a party and serve a copy on each other party as soon as possible.

The Notice of Lawyer for Party can be used at any time in a court proceeding.

Use this pathway to complete your Notice of Lawyer for Party.
